'''Anamnesis:''' assess the subjective sensation of mono- or binocularity of the disorder, and its laterality if monocular

'''On examination:''' when assessing visual acuity without and then with optical correction, a well-performed occultation of one eye and then the other enables the mono- or binocular nature of the visual disorder to be determined.

A visual problem is binocular if it disappears when either eye is occluded, and is only perceived when both eyes are open.

A visual disturbance is monocular when it persists after occlusion of the healthy eye.

question.title: What determines whether a visual disorder is binocular or monocular?
question.description: A visual problem is binocular if it disappears when either eye is occluded, and is only perceived when both eyes are open. A visual disturbance is monocular when it persists after occlusion of the healthy eye. Which of the following is a characteristic of a binocular visual disorder?

option_a.title: The visual disturbance persists after occlusion of both eyes
option_a.description: This option describes a characteristic of a monocular visual disturbance, not a binocular one

option_b.title: The visual problem disappears when either eye is occluded
option_b.description: This option describes a characteristic of a binocular visual disorder

option_c.title: The visual disturbance is only perceived when one eye is occluded
option_c.description: This option describes a characteristic of a monocular visual disturbance, not a binocular one

option_d.title: The visual problem is perceived when both eyes are closed
option_d.description: This option is not a characteristic of either binocular or monocular visual disorders

correct_option.title: The visual problem disappears when either eye is occluded
